channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Kremlin Wants Information. To Get It, Agents Show Up With Flowers.
item.media:description: Nataliya Gryaznevich, an employee of a pro-democracy group, said the man who approached at her apartment in Moscow “acted like an old friend I didn’t recognize.”
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: It took a while for a young woman to figure out that the smiling man who asked her for coffee was trying to recruit her as an informer.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: U.K. Charges 2 Men in Novichok Poisoning, Saying They’re Russian Agents
item.media:description: The suspects were identified as Alexander Petrov, left, and Ruslan Boshirov.
item.description: The police said they had tracked in detail the movement of the suspects, who have been charged in the poisoning of a former spy.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Marseilles Dispatch: Yes, There Is a French McDonald’s That Is Beloved (by Its Staff)
item.media:description: Workers at a McDonald’s in Marseille, France, are fighting to save the fast-food outlet from closing.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The owner of a McDonald’s in Marseille wants to sell it to a halal food operator. The employees — many of whom are Muslim and North African — are outraged.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Bombings Target Afghan Wrestling Match and Those Who Rushed to the Scene
item.media:description: An injured boy receiving help outside a hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, after two bombings at a wrestling training center. The second blast was far larger, and timed to kill emergency workers and journalists.
item.description: At least 20 people were killed and 70 wounded in the blasts in Kabul, including emergency workers and journalists who were reporting live on Afghan television.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and FATIMA FAIZI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Museum Fire in Brazil Was ‘Bound to Happen’
item.media:description: Employees of the National Museum in Rio de Janeiro on Monday. There had been warnings for years that the building was vulnerable to fire.
item.description: Warnings, including a citizen complaint to the federal prosecutor, that neglect had turned the National Museum into a tinderbox piled up for years.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: Airport Security Trays Carry More Cold Germs Than Toilets, Study Finds
item.media:description: Scientists working to prevent the spread of diseases through public transportation tested surfaces at Helsinki Airport, and found viral traces on half the security trays they looked at.
item.description: Scientists who tested surfaces at Helsinki Airport found the viruses responsible for colds and influenza on the trays used at security checkpoints.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Rx for British Doctors: Use Plain English Instead of Latin
item.media:description: Specialist doctors in England currently write explanatory letters to their patients’ general practitioners, rather than to the patients themselves, often employing medical jargon.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In an effort to improve written communication with patients, an initiative by the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges is encouraging doctors to ditch medical jargon.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: As a Major Storm Tapers in Japan, Fears Grow of Economic Losses
item.media:description: Flooding at Kansai International Airport on Tuesday after Typhoon Jebi hit western Japan. The airport is built on an artificial island.
item.media:credit: Kentaro Ikushima/Mainichi Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.description: The strongest typhoon to hit the country in 25 years could force the shutdown of the country’s third-largest airport for a week, crimping tourism and trade.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Pompeo Offers Pakistan a Reset, but Skepticism Is Rife
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in Washington last month. His brief stop in Pakistan will be followed by a visit to India.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The cancellation of $300 million in aid to Pakistan looms over a meeting between the secretary of state with the new Pakistani prime minister, Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Some Say the Press Is the Enemy. We Beg to Differ.
item.media:description: Capt. Harith al-Sudani’s wife, Raghad Hasan Chaloob, and their three children, Riyam, Rawan and Muamal.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: Over the course of one month, three separate stories from our International desk — reported on the ground in Iraq, Thailand and South Africa — helped lead to immediate reforms.
item.dc:creator: MARIE TAE McDERMOTT

item.title: Pence Expresses Support for Jailed Reuters Reporters
item.media:description: The detained Reuters journalists Wa Lone, left, and Kyaw Soe Oo after being sentenced Monday in Yangon, Myanmar.
item.description: The journalists were sentenced to seven years in prison on Monday in what was widely seen worldwide as an unjust case.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: South Korean Envoy Visits North Korea to Help Revive Nuclear Talks
item.media:description: Chung Eui-yong, third from right, and other members of South Korea’s delegation, just before leaving for North Korea on Wednesday.
item.description: An adviser to President Moon Jae-in met with Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader, hoping to jump-start the stalled diplomacy over nuclear disarmament.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Trump Plans to Take Aim at Iran in U.N. Session
item.media:description: President Trump will press the United Nations Security Council to be more assertive toward Iran at a session this month, raising the possibility of a face-to-face confrontation with Iranian officials.
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump will press the Security Council to be more assertive, raising the possibility of a face-to-face confrontation with Iranian officials.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Guatemalan Leader Bars Re-entry of Corruption Prosecutor
item.media:description: Iván Velásquez, above, the head of a United Nations-backed anticorruption commission, was barred from re-entering Guatemala by President Jimmy Morales.
item.description: The move by President Jimmy Morales puts him in direct conflict with Guatemala’s highest court and pushes the country toward a constitutional crisis.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Seeks Death Penalty in Trial of Outspoken Cleric
item.media:description: Salman al-Awda, a prominent Muslim cleric, has been critical of the Saudi government.
item.description: Salman al-Awda is being tried on 37 charges, including provoking public discord and disobeying the ruler.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: U.K. Economy Needs Stronger Unions and Higher Taxes on Rich, Report Says
item.media:description: Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury, at Westminster Abbey earlier this year. “For decades the U.K. economy has not worked as it should,” he said recently.
item.description: A report by the archbishop of Canterbury and others calls for transformational changes to redress the feelings of inequality and injustice that led to Brexit.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Brett Kavanaugh, Colin Kaepernick, Amazon: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB, STEPHEN REISS and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Greek Court Rules for Russia in Fight Over Cybercrime Suspect
item.media:description: The Greek police detained Aleksandr V. Vinnik last year on an American warrant that accuses him of running a Moscow-based Bitcoin exchange that laundered money.
item.description: The court ordered the man to be sent back home, not to the United States, though his background in cryptocurrency coincides with an area of interest to the special counsel.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Deadly Airstrikes in Syria Raise Fears of New Offensive
item.media:description: Russian airstrikes hit the rebel-hold town of Muhambal in Idlib Province on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Dozens of airstrikes hit Idlib Province, Syria’s last rebel-held enclave, as diplomats scrambled to avert a blood bath.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: U.S. Embassy Bombing Attempt in Cairo Misfires
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Cairo on Tuesday after a crude explosive device went off outside its gates.
item.description: The bomb, carried in a backpack, exploded prematurely, foiling the attacker’s plot, Egyptian officials said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MOHAMED EZZ

item.title: Kolkata Bridge Collapse Leaves at Least One Dead and Several Trapped
item.media:description: A crowd looked on as Indian Army and rescue personnel worked at the site of a collapsed bridge in Kolkata on Tuesday.
item.description: The state’s governor told reporters that “the bridge deserved better maintenance” and that there had been previous complaints about the soundness of the structure.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Brexit Gave Labour Party an Opening. Instead, It Has an Anti-Semitism Crisis.
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, ahead of a meeting of the party’s National Executive Committee in London on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Nick Ansell/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Britain’s Labour Party is seeking once and for all to end a rift over anti-Semitism. But the infighting has exposed damaging divisions.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Understanding the times: Satellite Images and Shadow Analysis: How The Times Verifies Eyewitness Videos
item.media:description: Using WhatsApp, a Syrian medic was one of six sources who confirmed the location of a tunnel entrance to a hospital near the site of a chemical attack in Syria.
item.description: Visual investigations based on social media posts require a mix of traditional journalistic diligence and cutting-edge internet skills.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPH KOETTL

item.title: Amazon Hits $1,000,000,000,000 in Value, Following Apple
item.media:description: Amazon’s founder and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, is richer, by far, than anyone in the modern world.
item.description: Apple became the first public company to be worth $1 trillion. Amazon hit the same milestone a month later, but the reasons for the e-commerce titan’s rise are more complicated.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STREITFELD

item.title: Near Everest’s Slopes, a Helicopter Rescue Fraud Preys on Trekkers
item.media:description: Rescue helicopter landing pads at the airport in Lukla, Nepal, near Mount Everest.
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.description: The Nepali government says that a wave of fraudulent claims and unneeded evacuations has cost insurance companies millions of dollars this year alone.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: A Top Chinese Official (Not Xi Jinping) Will Visit North Korea
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, right, with Li Zhanshu in March. Mr. Li, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, will lead a Chinese delegation to the North Korean capital this week.
item.description: There had been speculation that China’s president would attend national celebrations in Pyongyang this week, but state media said he would send an envoy.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Scores of Dead Elephants Found in Botswana ‘Poaching Frenzy’
item.media:description: In Botswana, the tusks of 87 elephants had been chopped off — evidence of what conservationists are calling one of the biggest slaughters in recent years.
item.description: At least 87 corpses were counted during aerial surveys over the past few months, all with their tusks hacked off.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF

item.title: Pakistan’s Military Has Quietly Reached Out to India for Talks
item.media:description: Naval officers at an Independence Day ceremony last month in Karachi, Pakistan.
item.description: Officials said India rebuffed Pakistan’s outreach, which was driven by anxiety over its isolation and flagging economy.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Japan Copes With Aftermath of Jebi, Strongest Typhoon in 25 Years
item.media:description: Huge waves caused by Typhoon Jebi hit a fishing port in Aki, in Kochi Prefecture on Japan’s western coast, on Tuesday.
item.description: Rescuers on Wednesday began evacuating thousands of people who were trapped at a major airport by the storm, which left 11 people dead and hundreds injured.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH and MAKIKO INOUE

item.title: Taliban Say Haqqani Founder Is Dead. His Group Is More Vital Than Ever.
item.media:description: Jalaluddin Haqqani in 1998.
item.description: Jalaluddin Haqqani was a Cold War ally of the C.I.A. Through his son’s Taliban leadership, his group has become central to the war against the Americans.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: You’ve Heard of Outsourced Jobs, but Outsourced Pollution? It’s Real, and Tough to Tally Up
item.media:description: A steel factory in Wu’an, China. Many countries can report lower carbon emissions because they are increasing imports of materials like steel or cement.
item.description: What Happens When Nations ‘Outsource’ Their Emissions? Headaches for Measuring Progress.
item.dc:creator: BRAD PLUMER

item.title: Rome Dispatch: When in Rome, Sea Gulls Do as They Please
item.media:description: The sea gull population in Rome has grown in recent years to the tens of thousands, some experts say. And they’re big.
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.description: Thousands of enormous sea gulls have aggressively colonized Rome, acting as if they own the place: invading homes and targeting the Vatican’s peace doves. Then, there’s the stench.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Duterte Orders Arrest of Philippine Senator, One of His Top Critics
item.media:description: “If the ordinary folk are being killed, he is now jailing his critics,” Senator Antonio Trillanes said Tuesday of President Rodrigo Duterte. Mr. Duterte says a 2010 amnesty granted to the senator over his role in two military rebellions was invalid.
item.description: The senator, Antonio Trillanes, said that the order was the act of a “dictator” but that he would not resist arrest. He would be the second presidential critic in the Senate to go to jail.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Amazon’s Plan to Reach 500 Million Indians: Speak Their Language
item.media:description: Amazon is aiming to break the English-language barrier in India. The e-commerce giant on Tuesday began offering its local website and apps in Hindi, India’s most popular language.
item.description: As the online retailer looked at India, its top new market, it realized it needed to reach beyond the relatively small, urban English-speaking population.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: A Facebook War: Libyans Battle on the Streets and on Screens
item.media:description: A mortar shell landed in this market in Tripoli, Libya, last week. A parallel battle was heating up on Facebook.
item.description: A new wave of fighting shook Tripoli this past week. For many combatants Facebook, which has huge influence in Libya, is a key weapon.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY

item.title: An Old Sore for Mexico’s Next President: The 43 Missing Students
item.media:description: Family members of the students who disappeared four years ago in Iguala, Guerrero, marching in Mexico City last month.
item.media:credit: Irvin Olivares/Agencia El Universal, via Associated Press
item.description: Four years after student protesters were pulled off buses, never to be seen again, some hope President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador can help.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

item.title: Double Blow to Brazil Museum: Neglect, Then Flames
item.media:description: The National Museum of Brazil in Rio de Janeiro on Monday, a day after it was ravaged by fire.
item.description: When Brazilians look at the shell of their National Museum, some see a symbol of the hollowing out of their country and the near-abandonment of basic services.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI, ERNESTO LONDOÑO and LIS MORICONI

item.title: News Analysis: Pope Francis Embraces Silence as Calls Grow for Response to Allegations
item.media:description: Pope Francis last week at the Vatican.
item.description: Amid rising clamor for the pontiff to address claims he covered up abuse, Francis extolled the virtues of silence: “The truth is humble, the truth is silent.”
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Mediterranean Death Rate Is Highest Since 2015 Migration Crisis
item.media:description: A woman’s body and a migrant who survived were pulled from the Mediterranean Sea by a Spanish agency about 85 miles off the Libyan coast in July.
item.description: For every 18 migrants reaching Italy from North Africa, one drowned — even as unauthorized migration along the route has fallen to its lowest level since 2015.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: Is There a Spy Camera in That Bathroom? In Seoul, 8,000 Workers Will Check
item.media:description: A volunteer and a police officer inspecting a women’s bathroom in Seoul, South Korea, in 2016. More than 30,000 cases of surreptitious filming have been reported nationally since 2013.
item.description: The South Korean capital is promising a large-scale campaign to combat cameras hidden in public toilets. The recordings often end up on pornographic websites.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY and SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: She Thought Pole Dancing at Kindergarten Was a Great Idea. Others Disagreed.
item.description: The principal of a Chinese kindergarten said she wanted to show children different kinds of dance. Parents and Chinese internet users were astonished.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: WPP Advertising Agency Names Mark Read as Chief Executive
item.media:description: Mark Read was named as the new chief executive of WPP on Monday.
item.description: Mr. Read, 51, is a longtime executive at the global marketing giant. He fills the position previously held by Martin Sorrell, who recently quit amid a personal misconduct investigation.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: The New New World: China’s Internet Obsesses Over Arrest of JD.com Founder Richard Liu
item.media:description: Richard Liu, the founder JD.com, has long been the subject of significant media attention in China. His recent arrest in Minnesota has only intensified that.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: The furor over Mr. Liu’s legal troubles reflects China’s fascination with self-made tech tycoons, who have become symbols of the country’s rise as a global power.
item.dc:creator: LI YUAN

item.title: Sweden Was Long Seen as a ‘Moral Superpower.’ That May Be Changing.
item.media:description: A member of the Sweden Democrats, a far-right party, speaking to voters at a gathering in Stockholm for representatives of all the political parties.
item.media:credit: Loulou d'Aki for The New York Times
item.description: In coming national elections, the anti-immigrant Sweden Democrats are forecast to get 20 percent, throwing the country’s image as a “moral superpower” into question.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Muslim Court Canes Malaysian Women for Same-Sex Relationship
item.media:description: The two women, each of whom was caned six times, after pleading guilty to homosexual activity at the Shariah High Court in the state of Terengganu, Malaysia, on Monday.
item.description: The women were each struck six times in a Shariah court. Human rights and legal groups called the punishment a form of torture that should be banned.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: What Artifacts Were in the National Museum of Brazil?
item.media:description: A firefighter removing items during Sunday’s fire at the National Museum of Brazil in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: The items feared lost to a fire on Sunday include one of the world’s largest meteorites and the oldest human fossil from the region.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: German Politicians Call for Surveillance of Anti-Immigrant Party
item.media:description: Journalists outside the district court in Landau, Germany, on Monday, where Abdul D. was tried. The hearing was private, because the case was handled as a juvenile offense.
item.description: After violent clashes in the city of Chemnitz, opponents accused the nationalist Alternative for Germany of undermining the country’s Constitution.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Myanmar Sentences Reuters Journalists to 7 Years in Prison
item.media:description: The Reuters journalist U Wa Lone after his sentencing in Yangon, Myanmar, on Monday.
item.description: The case has been the most visible instance of a wider crackdown on the press in Myanmar, which continues to deny atrocities against Rohingya Muslims.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
